level1.name: ğŸ“š A storybook you read at home
level1.explanation: A printed storybook is just paper with ink. It doesn't learn, change, or respond to you - the words stay the same every time you read it.

level1.name: ğŸ¤– Robot vacuum cleaner moving by itself
level1.explanation: Robot vacuums use AI to map your home, avoid obstacles, and figure out the best path to clean every spot without getting stuck.

level1.name: ğŸ”Š Voice on a smart speaker answering questions
level1.explanation: Smart speakers like Alexa and Google Home use AI to understand your voice, figure out what you're asking, and find the right answer.

level1.name: ğŸ® A video game character that responds to your playing style
level1.explanation: Some video games use AI to make characters smarter. They learn your playing style and adapt to make the game more challenging or fun.

level1.name: ğŸ“º Automatic captions on YouTube videos
level1.explanation: YouTube uses AI called speech recognition to listen to videos and automatically write out what people are saying as text captions.

level1.name: ğŸ“² Phone unlocking with your face
level1.explanation: Face unlock uses AI to recognise your unique facial features. It can tell the difference between you and other people, or even a photo of you!

level1.name: ğŸŒ Translation app that listens and speaks in another language
level1.explanation: Translation apps use AI to understand speech in one language and convert it to another. They learn from millions of translated sentences.

level1.name: ğŸš² A bicycle you ride to school
level1.explanation: A bicycle is powered by you! It uses simple machines like gears, chains, and wheels - no computer brain needed.

level1.name: ğŸ A toaster that browns bread
level1.explanation: A toaster uses a simple timer and heating element. It doesn't learn or think - it just heats up for the time you set.

level1.name: ğŸ“» A radio that plays music when you turn it on
level1.explanation: A basic radio receives signals from radio stations and converts them to sound. It doesn't make decisions or learn your preferences.

level1.name: ğŸ“º A regular TV remote
level1.explanation: A TV remote just sends simple signals to your TV when you press buttons. It doesn't understand or learn anything.

level1.name: ğŸ“· A printed photo album
level1.explanation: A photo album is just printed pictures in a book. Unlike phone photos apps, it can't recognise faces or organise pictures automatically.

level1.name: ğŸ”¦ A flashlight that turns on with a switch
level1.explanation: A flashlight is a simple circuit - flip the switch, and electricity flows to make light. No thinking involved!

level1.name: ğŸ•°ï¸ A clock with hands that tick
level1.explanation: An analog clock uses gears and springs (or a small motor) to move the hands. It tells time through mechanical movement, not intelligence.

level1.name: ğŸ“± TikTok videos that change based on what you watch
level1.explanation: TikTok uses AI to learn what videos you like and recommends similar ones. It watches what you watch, like, and skip to figure out your preferences.

level1.name: ğŸ¤³ Snapchat filter that changes your face
level1.explanation: Snapchat filters use AI to detect your face, find your eyes, nose, and mouth, then add effects that move with you in real-time.

level2.name: ğŸšª Automatic Doors
level2.explanation: It just uses a simple sensor to see when something is in front of it. It doesn't learn or think.

level2.name: ğŸ§® A Calculator
level2.explanation: It only follows pre-programmed math rules. It can't learn to solve new kinds of problems.

level2.name: ğŸ¿ A Microwave
level2.explanation: You tell it exactly how long to cook for. It follows your instructions and doesn't make its own decisions.

level2.name: ğŸ¨ AI Art Generator
level2.explanation: It learned from millions of pictures to create a brand new image based on your text description.

level2.name: ğŸš¦ Traffic Lights
level2.explanation: Most traffic lights just follow a simple timer pattern. They don't watch the traffic to change their timing.

level2.name: ğŸš— A Remote Control Car
level2.explanation: It only does what you tell it to do with the controller. It doesn't drive by itself.

level2.name: âœï¸ Spell Check
level2.explanation: It not only spots a wrong word but often understands the sentence to suggest the correct one.

level2.name: ğŸ—£ï¸ Siri or Google Assistant
level2.explanation: It understands your voice, answers questions, and learns what you like.

level2.name: â–¶ï¸ YouTube Recommendations
level2.explanation: It watches what videos you like and suggests new ones it thinks you'll enjoy.

level2.name: ğŸ¬ Netflix 'For You' Row
level2.explanation: It learns from the shows you watch to guess what other shows you might want to see next.

level1.name: ğŸš A drone flying itself to take videos
level1.explanation: Autonomous drones use AI for obstacle avoidance, path planning, and tracking subjects. They make real-time decisions about flight without human control.

level1.name: ğŸ¥ The software that helps doctors spot diseases in scans
level1.explanation: Medical AI analyses thousands of images to learn patterns of diseases, helping doctors identify conditions like cancer or fractures more accurately.

level1.name: ğŸ’¬ Chatbot that answers your questions online
level1.explanation: Modern chatbots use natural language processing AI to understand your questions and generate relevant responses, learning from millions of conversations.

level1.name: ğŸ® A video game that changes difficulty based on your skill
level1.explanation: Adaptive difficulty systems use AI to monitor your performance and dynamically adjust the game's challenge level to keep you engaged.

level1.name: âœï¸ An app that writes stories or poems for you
level1.explanation: Generative AI models have been trained on vast amounts of text to understand language patterns and create original creative writing based on prompts.

level1.name: ğŸ­ Deepfake videos that swap faces realistically
level1.explanation: Deepfakes use deep learning AI to analyse facial features and movements, then convincingly map one person's face onto another in video footage.

level1.name: ğŸ“° A printed newspaper article
level1.explanation: A newspaper is static printed text written by human journalists. It doesn't adapt, learn, or change based on who reads it.

level1.name: ğŸ¥« A hand-powered can opener
level1.explanation: A can opener is a simple mechanical tool that uses leverage and a cutting wheel. It requires human power and doesn't make any decisions.

level1.name: ğŸ”¢ A regular calculator that only adds and subtracts
level1.explanation: A basic calculator follows fixed mathematical rules programmed into it. It cannot learn new operations or solve problems it wasn't designed for.

level1.name: âŒš A mechanical wristwatch
level1.explanation: A mechanical watch uses springs, gears, and an escapement mechanism to keep time. It's pure precision engineering with no computational intelligence.

level1.name: ğŸš´ A bike that you pedal to move
level1.explanation: A bicycle converts your pedalling energy into motion through gears and a chain. It's entirely human-powered with no electronic components.

level1.name: ğŸ“¸ A regular camera that uses film
level1.explanation: A film camera uses optics and chemical processes to capture images. Unlike digital cameras with AI features, it has no computational processing.

level1.name: ğŸ’¡ A light bulb you turn on with a switch
level1.explanation: A light bulb is a simple electrical circuit. When you flip the switch, electricity flows through the filament to produce light - no intelligence needed.

level1.name: ğŸš¥ A traffic light controlled by timers, not sensors
level1.explanation: Timer-based traffic lights follow a fixed schedule regardless of actual traffic conditions. They don't sense, learn, or adapt to their environment.

level1.name: ğŸµ The app suggesting new songs after you listen to music
level1.explanation: Music apps like Spotify use AI to analyse your listening habits, find patterns in the songs you like, and recommend new music you're likely to enjoy.

level1.name: ğŸ“¢ Online ads that seem to know what you like
level1.explanation: These ads use AI to track your browsing behaviour and predict what products you might want to buy, creating a personalised advertising experience.

level2.name: ğŸ” Face ID to Unlock a Phone
level2.explanation: It uses machine learning to create a unique map of your face and recognises it even with small changes.

level2.name: ğŸ¤– ChatGPT
level2.explanation: A generative AI that understands context, answers complex questions, and creates original text based on patterns from a massive dataset.

level2.name: ğŸ“§ Email Spam Filter
level2.explanation: It learns to identify the features of junk mail (keywords, sender, links) and automatically sorts it for you.

level2.name: ğŸ—ºï¸ Google Maps Real-Time Traffic
level2.explanation: It analyses live data from many phones to predict traffic jams and suggest faster routes, constantly learning traffic patterns.

level2.name: ğŸš™ Basic Cruise Control
level2.explanation: It's an automated system that just maintains a speed you set. It doesn't sense other cars or conditions.

level2.name: ğŸ§ An ATM
level2.explanation: It follows a secure, pre-programmed set of steps. It cannot make decisions outside of its programming.

level2.name: ğŸ“² A QR Code Scanner
level2.explanation: It's a simple decoder. It translates a visual pattern into data (like a website link) without any learning or inference.

level2.name: ğŸŒ¡ï¸ A Digital Thermostat
level2.explanation: It's a simple sensor and switch. It turns the heating or cooling on or off when the temperature goes past a set point.

level2.name: ğŸ“± TikTok 'For You' Page
level2.explanation: The algorithm learns your viewing habits with incredible detail to create a highly personalised and addictive feed.

level2.name: ğŸ¯ Personalised Ads
level2.explanation: An AI tracks your browsing history and online behaviour to predict what products you are most likely to buy.
